Today, we're beginning a new series on how innovation happens in education, and we are doing it with this headline - The Omniscient Robo Tutor In The Sky Is Ready To Teach Your Child.

The idea is that teachers can tap into big data and algorithms to help each child learn at his or her own pace.
Here's NPR's Eric Westervelt.
It's a long-standing criticism of K-12 teachers - they too often teach to the middle, it's said, leaving struggling students feeling lost and more advanced students, bored.
Often everyone gets the same books, the same material, same homework, same difficulty level.
And overworked, underpaid, time-stressed teachers don't necessarily have the time to personalize every lesson and drill deep into what each child is struggling with.
The ed-tech company Knewton, with a K, thinks it has finally created a technological solution.

That's Knewton founder and CEO Jose Ferreira.
He believes his new free online tutoring platform, built on data-rich content in the cloud, will radically change how teachers personalize instruction through automation.

We can take the combined data power of millions of students - all the people who are just like you - who ever had to learn a particular concept before that, you have to learn today - to find the best pieces of content proven most effective for people just like you and give that to you every single time you come.
Through multiple choice questions, videos and quizzes, the platform starts to assess how each tool works with each student.
